This was a fun game even before Overwatch's... decline, but now that the once-vaunted king of hero shooters has irrevocably proven itself to be one of the most legendarily mishandled projects in the medium, it seems it's time for Paladins to really shine. Yes, it's a bit janky -- there can be crashes and visual bugs - but frankly it feels like a welcome return to genre classics, a candy-colored arena shooter with character that aren't even trying to look like they wouldn't be at home doodled in the margins of various teenagers' notebooks. I don't much care for its ranked mode, but then again, I don't much care for ANY ranked mode, because my idea of a good time does not involve listening to grown men bicker with one another. I will say that while it's fine and dandy that the majority of these little loot box items can be directly bought, I feel as though the actual prices are a bit high for what you're getting. Something closer to the standard league of legends monetization model (yes, I know, ptooey ptooey, throw salt over your shoulders now) seems like it would be a better move for the company.

I bought the Paladins Founder's Pack way back when the game came out and I enjoyed it but it had its drawbacks and I found myself playing Overwatch much more than Paladins. But with all the new heroes and the huge changes the game has gone through in the years since, I've recently come back to it and found that it's by far my favorite team shooter.

There are heroes for all different kinds of play styles and most heroes can adapt via the in-match loadouts and purchases to the situations that come up. (No tank? Pick up some extra HP and damage reduction since you'll likely be taking more damage, etc.)

I know the game systems have changed so that free-to-play players can't feasibly get all the heroes unlocked anymore so I can't recommend it for them, but for anyone who just buys the hero pack with all current heroes, it's a really great game with a lot of depth and a ton of fun with friends.

This game hands down deserves a recommendation. From great gameplay to wonderful cosmetics, this game is a blast. I can’t tell you how much I enjoy this game. Although the micro transactions are a little annoying, other than that this game is exactly what it should be. The occasional bug here and there, but they have a wonderful dev team that works to fix these bugs quickly. There is such a large variety of champions and the item shop system in game is what makes it so unique compared to other games in the genre. I highly recommend this to anybody willing to play it.

After playing this game for a decent amount of time, I have to say that I enjoy it. It gets a lot of flack for being an Overwatch rip-off, but there are a lot of things in this game that HiRez and Mojo do really well, such as the events that are pretty constant. It's still in constant development, but if you join the Paladins Discord server, you can help them fix any bugs or issues that you have with the game. The only negative thing that I could say about this game is that there is no blocking a person that may flame you. Even if you report this person (I'm not really sure that reporting people does a whole lot, I haven't seen anyone complaining of being banned or anything like that), if you enter the same style match that you were just in, it's fairly common to get put into the same lobby as them again. Other that that, the actual gameplay is fun and the mechanics are pretty fluid.

Paladins gets gameplay right. Some comparrisons with Overwatch.

Map Design:
Hi-Rez shows it has much more experience with action games like this through map design.  Although some might argue less interesting, the symmetric map layouts simply play better with much less choke points resulting in an experience that is much more dynamic and much less choked gameplay.

Blizzard wins with visual polish and there substantially larger development team shows what it is really possible.

Gameplay:
Hi-Rez wins due to better map layouts, more unique champion variety, higher (but not by much) time to kills (therefore more skill based), and most importantly less ultimate spam that totally alters the outcome of the match.  Some champions are very strong in lower skill games, some very strong in higher skilled matchups, overall there is a place where each can shine.

Although the idea of mounts in a game like this is kinda funny, they work well as a mechanic to get back into the action much quicker.

In Overwatch health packs are occasionally available for pickup.  Paladins has a time out of combat mechanic which grants health recovery.  I prefer the Paladins approach which results, in general, with more action less respawns.

Strategy:
Double edged sword for Hi-Rez.  In Paladins a game can be lost even before it's played.    Things that can result in a loss:
- Poor champion deck loadouts.  5 Cards with 15 possible points are chosen to establish a premade deck for a champion outside of gameplay.  Players can build decks to optimize champion strengths, or just the opposite and hinder their performance.
- Poor pre-match champion selection: champions cannot be changed or adapted mid match.  Weak or no front line pick?  Most of the time a loss.  No support pick, most of the time a loss.  
- Poor in-game item purchases.  Credits are earned during the match and can be spent to slightly enchance stats like damage reduction, attach strengths vs. shields or deployables, health steal, etc..  Poorly spend in-match credits can actually lead to a loss if there are enough poor choices on a team.

The Paladins experience is more rich as a result of the strategic decision making, but can also be more sour when teammates haven't taken the time to understand some of these basics.  

Overwatch is much more accessible for the beginner to these types of games.

Technical Performance:
Overwatch by far wins this category.  They have created an experience with substantially less glitches, UI bugs, and general problems.  Hi-Rez seems like it is forced into continued champion release patches to maintain similar numbers and it shows that they still have a long way to go to correct game bugs.  This can make for a frusterating experince when players are disconnected from matches while loading and don't understand they can reconnect.  

Overall this game is a great experience and I recommend it for anyone who enjoys shooter style action games with some strategy elements.

This game used to be a much bigger dumpster fire than it is as of this review. A lot of bugs that were ignored by dev team for YEARS have finally been fixed. That being said, it's still got a long way to go. The focus is on quantity over quality and often new content is a 50/50 tossup of incredibly well executed skins/other items OR a bunch of lazy stuff that was obviously crunched into the patch.

HiRez has a pretty "ignorant" history as far as transparency and support for the community has gone. They're learning, but they still have made enough mistakes that this game will never truly be as amazing as it deserves to be - and I think that kinda sums up every veteran players' opinion: too little too late. HiRez/Evil Mojo are finally figuring out how to be the good guys, but I GENUINELY HOPE this game stays alive and supported, or is replaced with a relevant sequel/spiritual successor instead of being dumped out of the blue like other HiRez IPs

This was a fun game once.  It had great unique characters, it was skill based, and it had outplay.  This last feature made Paladins extremely unique for a modern FPS.  You didn't just die if someone else pressed a button, it was what separated Paladins from Overwatch for me and it was what I genuinely enjoyed about the game.  Fragging people took a little bit of effort and actually felt rewarding.

Over the last year the skill based and outplay based components were chipped away.  Old champions got their mobility nerfed into the ground.  New champions have little to no mobilty.  Weapon attacks are far more confirmable, projectiles got sped up and have even larger hitboxes, hit scan weapons fire faster and or do more damage, the list goes on.  This game became another utterly brainless modern shooter and ultimately lived up to the meme of being "Overwatch for poor people."

What finally prompted this review was Hi-Rez's actions over the last month.  Keep in mind, I am an older gamer.  I remember the days of UT2k4 and Tribes.  I can understand if the modern gaming generation doesn't enjoy those sorts of games.  It's perfectly acceptable if a company changes the direction of their game to appease the majority of their playerbase.  It's another thing to push out an extremely buggy mess of a patch that contains security vulnerabilities (don't link your twitch) whose major changes the community has been completely against during the entire month of testing.

This game is a mess.  Most aspects that made it unique have been stripped away.  What's left is a game that is almost indistguishable from any other modern shooter except for the copious amounts of bugs and a new card system that is P2W for the casual mode.  I would literally recommend Overwatch over this game and I desipse that game.

[b]**NEVERMIND, THEY FIXED IT**[/b]

[strike]This game was amazing. Keyword: was. Sure, it had bugs and balancing issues, but the game offered customization and strategy that no other modern FPS could offer. The character customization allowed for diverse playstyles, the focus on using credits to counter the other team was fun and rewarding, the character selection is huge and large updates are frequent. I could honestly say it was one of my favorite games.

Then OB64 came out. The character customization was turned from a fun strategy element into a grind-fest. Instead of prioritizing certain cards to better your playstyle, the game is centered around leveling up your cards with grinding and money. This makes the game extremely pay 2 win. The perks you get from buying cards sets you high above other players. Why even bother with this?

I wish this update never came out.[/strike]
Be good for play with friend!!

Was a good game. They are now adding a pay to win card system where you have to find cards in random loot boxes or be underpowered compared to others in the match. Therefore the game lost all value as a fair game, its just pay for power now, avoid until the system is removed. I uninstalled it right away for it, enough of those games on mobile thanks.

Paladins is an interesting, dynamic team FPS with many heroes and loadouts appealing to many playstyles.
While it may seem like an Overwatch clone, the two games are different in many ways and feel different.
Game frequently receives content patches (new heroes, maps and cosmetic awards) and balance patches.

Though it received quite a flak after the infamous OB64 patch, recent developments show that the company is willing to take the game in right directions with freeing it from mechanics resembling P2W.

Updated 24.11.2023:
Despite the fact that the game is now maintained by borderline skeleton crew, it still delivers a decent experience.
